question.text: What is the role of accessory pigments in photosynthesis?
question.option: To absorb additional wavelengths of light
question.answer: To absorb additional wavelengths of light
question.explanation: Accessory pigments like carotenoids expand the range of light wavelengths that can be used for photosynthesis by absorbing different colors than chlorophyll.

question.text: What molecule does Photosystem I pass its electrons to during non-cyclic electron flow?
question.explanation: In non-cyclic electron flow, Photosystem I transfers electrons to NADP+, which becomes reduced to NADPH for use in the Calvin cycle.

question.text: What is the first stable product of carbon fixation?
question.explanation: When RuBisCO fixes CO2 to RuBP, it forms two molecules of 3-phosphoglycerate (3-PGA), which is the first stable product of carbon fixation.

question.text: How many carbon dioxide molecules are needed to complete one turn of the Calvin cycle?
question.explanation: The Calvin cycle requires three CO2 molecules to be fixed to produce one three-carbon sugar molecule (G3P) that can be used to make glucose.

question.text: What happens to G3P produced in the Calvin cycle?
question.option: It is always converted to glucose
It can be used to regenerate RuBP or make glucose
It is converted back to CO2
It is used to make ATP
question.answer: It can be used to regenerate RuBP or make glucose
question.explanation: G3P (glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate) can either be used to regenerate RuBP to continue the Calvin cycle or be exported to make glucose and other organic molecules.
